Author: Mark Winch
Title: Octopath Traveler 0
Excerpt: A richly rewarding JRPG that asks for patience but pays it back.
Paragraph: Octopath Traveler 0 is one of those games that slowly pulls you in and refuses to let go. Not because it tries to impress you right away, but because it is simply a solid and generous JRPG. From the start, it is clear that even if the content is based on a mobile game, this is not a disguised gacha game or a stripped down experience. It feels like a real game that respects your time.

What stood out to me the most is how much content you get for your money. This is a game you can easily spend hundreds of hours with without ever feeling like you are grinding just to keep playing, which I cannot say for the first Octopath Traveler. The story unfolds at its own pace, but if you take the time to follow it, it becomes genuinely rewarding.

Multiple characters come back, long term plot points slowly evolve, and the narrative starts connecting pieces in ways I did not expect early on. I honestly expected the chapters to be less intertwined than this, having played the previous entries.

The gameplay stays true to what makes Octopath fun. The front row and back row system adds interesting strategies to combat, and the level of customization lets you constantly experiment with your party. You are encouraged to try different setups, switch roles, and develop your teams rather than relying on a single solution, even if you can easily break the game once you understand the mechanics well enough.
The core characters are strong overall, and while not every moment lands, there are story beats that genuinely surprised me.

The biggest issue is the pacing. It takes a long time, easily 15 to 20 hours, before the game really shows what it is capable of. Early on, it can feel a bit too simple, which may push some players away before things get interesting.

Some dialogue is also more repetitive than it needs to be, especially during slower scenes. I am looking at you, infamous "..." dialogue. The voice acting quality also varies depending on the character.
Once the game finds its rhythm, though, it becomes very hard to put down. It is a slow burn, but one that rewards patience.

At the end of the day, after more than 100 hours spent in its world, I can confidently say this. If there had been more content, I would have kept playing without hesitation. That alone says a lot about how much this game ended up winning me over.
GoodSummary: Does not feel like a gacha game
BadSummary: Voice acting is hit or miss
